learning_outcomes.description: Identify and apply the sources of taxation law and the regulatory framework in which taxation law is administered in Australia to solve real-world income tax problems and to professionally communicate these solutions to a range of stakeholders.

Develop the technical skills to independently analyse events and transactions to construct, explain and professionally communicate the calculation of taxable income and taxes payable to a range of stakeholders.
Analyse, calculate and explain the taxation issues associated with non-complex international transactions in an income tax and Good and Services Tax context using clear professional communication.
Develop the technical skills to independently analyse, calculate, explain and professionally communicate the Goods and Services Tax treatment of business transactions to a range of stakeholders.

Develop the technical skills to independently analyse, calculate, explain and professionally communicate the income tax and Fringe Benefits Tax treatment of employment entitlements to a range of stakeholders.

assessments.due_date:
Week 8, Tue

The In-Semester Exam online test link will only be accessible in a 15-minute exam window period from 8:00 am to 8:15 am on Tuesday 15 April 2025 on the course Blackboard website. It is each student’s own responsibility to access the In-Semester Exam test link during this exam window period. From when you access the In-Semester Exam test link, you have 90 minutes to complete the test. There is no additional planning time. Your test will close automatically at the end of this 90-minute exam duration.
assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester Examination is a timed, non-invigilated online exam, completed on the course Blackboard website.

  • This is an individual assessment activity. Students must work alone.
  • The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.
  • This is an open-book exam.
  • The In-Semester Examination covers Topics 1 to 5.
  • Total duration: 90 minutes. There is no additional planning time.
  • As the In-Semester Examination is a timed exam, students are expected to know the work covered in the exam and the In-Semester Examination is set on that basis. Therefore, no time allowance is made for students to look up answers.
  • The In-Semester Exam online test link will only be accessible in a 15-minute exam window period from 8:00 am to 8:15 am on Tuesday, 15 April 2025 on the course Blackboard website. It is each student’s own responsibility to access the In-Semester Exam test link during this exam window period. Students have one attempt at completing the In-Semester Exam. From when you access the In-Semester Exam test link, you have 90 minutes to complete the test. The test link will close automatically at the end of this exam duration.
  • The criteria, marking and performance standards will be made available on the course Blackboard website in the Assessment folder.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The In-Semester Exam online test link will only be accessible in a 15-minute exam window period from 8:00 am to 8:15 am on Tuesday 15 April 2025. It is each student’s own responsibility to access the In-Semester Exam test link on the course Blackboard website during this exam window period. The test closes and submits automatically at the end of 90 minutes. Late submission is not possible.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

Students must access each Tax Advice quiz in a 24-hour window period that starts at 8 am on Mondays in each quiz week (Teaching Week 3, 5, 7, 11 and 13). Students have one attempt at completing each Tax Advice quiz. From when you access the quiz test link, you have 60 minutes to complete each quiz. There is no additional planning time. The test will close and submit automatically at the end of each 60-minute quiz duration. Late submission is not possible.
assessments.task_description:
The Tax Advice quiz series aims to develop ethical, critical and professional decision making and professional communication skills and to help students keep up to date with the significant workload in LAWS3101 which aligns with the accreditation requirements of Chartered Accountants Australia New Zealand and CPA Australia.

There are five online Tax Advice quizzes. Each quiz is completed using a test link in Blackboard on the course website. Each quiz contributes a maximum of 5% to the total weighting for this assessment item. The total maximum mark for the quiz series is 20%. Students are permitted to complete all five quizzes. Each student's cumulative mark for all five quizzes will be calculated, with a maximum of 20%. Therefore, it is not the best four out of five quizzes that contribute to the mark for this assessment item, but all quiz marks as the main aim of this series is to develop key graduate attributes essential for the workplace.

  • This is an individual assessment activity. Students must work alone.
  • The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.
  • The quiz series is conducted as open-book assessments.
  • The topic/s, criteria, marking and performance standards for each quiz will be made available on the course Blackboard website in the Assessment folder. 
  • Each quiz can comprise different types of questions, including matching, multiple-choice, longer calculation and short essay questions.
  • Students must access each quiz in a 24-hour window period that starts at 8 am on Mondays in each quiz week (Teaching Week 3, 5, 7, 11 and 13). Students have one attempt at completing each quiz. From when you access the quiz test link, you have 60 minutes to complete each quiz. There is no additional planning time. The test will close and submit automatically at the end of each 60-minute quiz duration. Late submission is not possible.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Tax Advice quizzes are completed online using Blackboard test links on the course website. At the end of the quiz duration, the test link closes and submits automatically. Late submission is not possible.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The End-of-semester Exam is an on-campus, in-person, invigilated exam.

  • The End-of-semester Exam covers Topics 3 to 12.
  • Any written or printed materials (e.g. textbook, notes pages, dictionaries) are permitted in the exam. Materials may be annotated.
  • Students must use a UQ-approved calculator.
  • Duration: 120 minutes plus 10 minutes planning time.
  • As the End-of-semester Exam is a timed exam, students are expected to know all of the work covered in the exam and the End-of-semester Exam is set on that basis. Therefore, no time allowance is made for students to look up answers.
  • This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.
  • The criteria, marking and performance standards will be available on the course Blackboard website in the Assessment folder.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The program of lectures is detailed on the course Blackboard website.

Lectures run weekly, except in Teaching Week 8 when the In-Semester Examination is conducted during the timetabled lecture. In Teaching Weeks 1 to 6, lectures are timetabled for three hours. For the remainder of the semester, lectures are timetabled for two hours.

Lecture topics are as follows:

1.     Sources of taxation law, the taxation formula and taxes payable.

2.     Residence and source, receipt of foreign income, tax avoidance and tax administration.

3.     Principles of assessable income, income from personal services and employment.

4.     Income from business and property.

5.     General deductions.

6.     Specific deductions and capital allowances.

7.     Dividends and franking accounts.

8.     Trading stock and timing rules.

9.     Capital Gains Tax.

10. Tax structures and superannuation.

11. Goods and Services Tax (GST).

12. Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures The program of lectures is detailed on the course Blackboard website. Lectures run weekly, except in Teaching Week 8 when the In-Semester Examination is conducted during the timetabled lecture. In Teaching Weeks 1 to 6, lectures are timetabled for three hours. For the remainder of the semester, lectures are timetabled for two hours. Lecture topics are as follows: 1.     Sources of taxation law, the taxation formula and taxes payable. 2.     Residence and source, receipt of foreign income, tax avoidance and tax administration. 3.     Principles of assessable income, income from personal services and employment. 4.     Income from business and property. 5.     General deductions. 6.     Specific deductions and capital allowances. 7.     Dividends and franking accounts. 8.     Trading stock and timing rules. 9.     Capital Gains Tax. 10. Tax structures and superannuation. 11. Goods and Services Tax (GST). 12. Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT)

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(03 Mar - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

The tutorial program and tutorial exercises are available on the course Blackboard website in the Assessment folder.

There are 10 tutorials. Tutorials run in Teaching Weeks 2 to 7, 9 to 10, and 12 to 13.

Students are expected to prepare for and attend all tutorials. Because students are expected to prepare for and attend their tutorials, only limited written feedback is provided. Tutorials are not recorded.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
